Literature Review: Bioinformatic approaches have revolutionized the field of food science by enabling researchers to analyze protein structural models and uncover molecular drivers of food functionality. The integration of structural bioinformatics with protein databases has led to the development of tools that can rapidly extract relevant information from these databases. This information is then used to model protein functionality, including solubility, thermostability, and emulsification. The use of bioinformatic properties such as surface hydrophobicity, electrostatic potential, and protein secondary structure has been shown to be strongly correlated with physicochemical experimentation. In this review, we will discuss the current state of bioinformatic approaches for characterizing molecular structure and function of food proteins, highlighting the strengths and limitations of these methods. We will also explore the potential applications of these approaches in food science research and the future directions of this field.
